frameDefinitions: This frame contains words referring to teaching and the participants in teaching.
The Focal_feature is defined in relation to a Landmark_feature, either as a particular part, or as an immediately bordering entity.
A Speaker addresses an Audience on a particular Topic.
Two (or more) people (the Interlocutors, also encodable as Interlocutor_1 and Interlocutor_2) talk to one another.
An Inspector attains a degree of certainty in the Unconfirmed_content, generally by inspecting some evidence.
A Speaker addresses an Addressee with a Message, which may be indirectly referred to as a Topic.
frameExamples: Dad <t>taught</t> me that if you work hard, you will be OK - no matter what happens.
I'm on the <t>summit</t> of Mt. Shasta.
McNamara <t>addressed</t> congress on the state of affairs of the Department of Defense.
I would rather <t>discuss</t> politics with anyone but him.
listRoleDefinitions: One who instructs a <fen>Student</fen> in some area of knowledge or skill.
One who is instructed by a <fen>Teacher</fen> in skills or knowledge.
An educational establishment, such as a school or college.
The area of knowledge or skill which is taught by a <fen>Teacher</fen> or to a <fen>Student</fen>.
A formal Qualification such as an academic degree or a certificate for which a student is aiming.
An action which the <fen>Student</fen> is able to perform as a result of instruction.
A guideline for correct behavior. In most cases, this concerns morally or socially desirable actions.
A piece of information that the <fen>Student</fen> is informed of by the <fen>Teacher</fen>.
Educational <fen>Material</fen>, such as books, tapes, or videos, used by a <fen>Teacher</fen> or a <fen>Student</fen> to acquire skills or knowledge.
A role, typically professional or vocational,  that the <fen>Student</fen> is meant to be able to fill as a result of their training.
FN: a program of lectures or other matter dealing with a subject
The time when the teaching occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which the teaching takes place.

Consider whether a possible <fen>Place</fen> phrase is really where the training took place or is rather part of a description of the <fen>Institution</fen>.
A stable bounded area defined by its relation to another landform. This role is incorporated in each LU in this frame.
The landform with respect to which the <fen>Focal_feature</fen> is defined.
The person or persons to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> delivers their text.
The person who orally delivers a text about a <fen>Topic</fen> to a passive <fen>Audience</fen>.
What the text that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces is about.
The <fen>Time</fen> describes when the speaking occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location where the speaking occurs.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as compared with <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen> is generally encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>.  Thus a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that of <fen>Interlocutor_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Interlocutors</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> involved in a conversation are construed as two separate groups with different levels of volitionality or control, <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen> refers to the semantically and grammatically less prominent group.  It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by <ment>with</ment>).  Note that it is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents. For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Interlocutor_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Interlocutors</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Interlocutors</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Discussion frame, it is possible for the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.

<fen>Topic</fen> expresses the subject that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> are trying to come to some agreement about.  It may refer, for example, to an undesirable issue that the <fen>Interlocutors</fen> want to have the proper response to, or it may refer more directly to an unresolved question.
The time at which the discussion takes place.
The location at which a discussion takes place.
The individual or individuals that ascertain that the <fen>Unconfirmed_content</fen> is true.
An open proposition that the <fen>Inspector</fen> decides by examining evidence.  It is usually a propostion put forward which some parties would disbelieve or contest.
The <fen>Medium</fen> is the piece of text or work in which the <fen>Inspector</fen> verifies the <fen>Unconfirmed_content</fen>:
This role describes the <fen>Time</fen> at which the verification event takes place.
This role describes where the verificiation event takes place.
The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that produces the <fen>Message</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> receives the <fen>Message</fen> from the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the communication produced by the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is a general description of the content of the <fen>Message</fen>.
This role is the <fen>Medium</fen> in which the <fen>Message</fen> is expressed.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> informs the <fen>Addressee</fen> of the <fen>Message</fen>.
<fen>Place</fen> is the location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen> informs  the <fen>Addressee</fen> of the <fen>Message</fen>.
listRoleExamples: She's a <fex>French</fex> Teacher
She's Studying <fex>for a Master's degree</fex>
Taut with worry, Dad taught us <fex>how to drive</fex>.
My brother taught me <fex>not to be mean to guys when I'm not interested in them</fex>.
When I was two she taught me <fex>that a quarter was 25 cents and a dime was 10 cents</fex>.
All employees have received <fex>a booklet</fex> INSTRUCTING them on how to report ` anything from unwanted touching and uncalled-for blue jokes to overt demands for sexual favours . '
When his father died he went to live with an uncle in Ka'u who trained him <fex>as a warrior</fex> during his teenage years
He lectured <fex>to the officers of the Scots Guard</fex>  in  1929.
<fex>You</fex> have to sermonize about the good times
He was the Director: he could lecture <fex>on whomever he liked</fex>.
<fex>The President</fex> conferred with his top advisor.
The President debated <fex>with his top advisor</fex>.
(1) <fex>The President and his advisor</fex> discussed the Venezuelan situation briefly before the summit.
The President and his top advisors discussed <fex>the scandal</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex> the participants discussed taking down the last trade barriers without consensus.
We just conferred for a couple of hours <fex>up in her room</fex>.
<fex>His</fex> later verification of the facts is certainly beyond reproach.
It is extremely difficult to confirm <fex>the absence of something</fex>.
<fex>Chapter four</fex> confirms the reader 's suspicions completely.
<fex>Bill</fex> told me that he would come to the party.
The authorities informed me <fex>that my brother had been arrested</fex>.
Leroy told his mother <fex>about his arrest</fex>.

Even when we had a size problem they informed me <fex>right away</fex> and everything worked
out great.
She looked at it for a few moments, thinking of Mark Smeaton and what he had told her <fex>on the steps of City Hall</fex>.
